comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I don't know about the "Flag Crazies" but look at all those daft people looking out the windows?  Either there was an arrangement for a mass suicide or some parade or visiting dignitary was passing by?  The carriage with military/police escort in the foreground of the original shot might have been the tail of something big.  I did several searches yesterday to see if I could get any mention of an Australian or Commonwealth event in Belfast in the 1900's but to no avail.  Would the Belfast newspapers have anything on line or are they behind a paywall?  Well done Carol, prividing a quality service as always!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Post 1903, if wikipedia is to be believed:  "Prime Minister Edmund Barton announced in the Commonwealth Gazette that King Edward VII had officially recognised the design as the Flag of Australia on 11 February 1903. This version made all the stars in the Southern Cross seven-pointed apart from the smallest, and is the same as the current design except the six-pointed Commonwealth Star. "

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Newspapers of the day are being black and white and read all over by me at the moment. Nothing to report yet...

comment._content: Wondering why the flags were flying outside Mackenzie & McMullen who were drapers... Something as simple as they had flagpoles? Or some other significance?

comment.author: 60812213@N04
comment._content: Edward VII was crowned on 9 August 1902.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abandonedrailsireland] The trams were only electrified in 1905 though, and although the car in the related image could conceivably be a 1902 Mercedes, it looks newer.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] This version made all the stars in the Southern Cross seven-pointed apart from the smallest AND the Commonwealth Star which didn't become 7 pointed until 1908.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: White Ensign is a naval flag. still to confirm the rest en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_British_flags first one appears to be a colonial flag, not sure which one it is.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: That one with the harp almost looks like the Green Ensign here... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Ensign

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: the flag closest to the camera would seem to have 2 laurel wreaths or sheafs (?) of wheat surrounding a coat of arms topped with a crown. A flag for the Governor General or the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland? I cropped the image of the first flag, turned it left 90degrees so the flag would appear to be flying normally. When I lighten the image, it almost appears to be the coat of arms of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, kind of like on this passport but without the lion and unicorn... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Passport_UKGBI.PNG Here it is on my photostream, www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02/7884948802/in/photostream. Can almost see what it is...

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: "The Empire Day movement, founded by the Earl of Meath in 1902, seems only to have taken a significant hold over Belfast by 1908-09..." books.google.ca/books?id=WUTpAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA128&lp... Page 128. It would make sense that this is some sort of Royal flag then...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] I think the first flag is a Canadian one. See all the various contemporary Canadian "unofficial" flags here - www.loeser.us/flags/canada.html and here - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Red_Ensign

Watching the 'Detectives' ... incredible.These guys should be solving missing people, because the detail that they go through is impressive to say the least.
Always amazed at the intensity of the detail!
